text: it's the age-old question why do people
cheat there's all kinds of sociological
reasons psychological reasons and I also
think genetic reasons people tend to
cheat more if they live in a big city
where they don't have a whole lot of
family around them let's say they moved
to to New York from our tiny little town
in Nevada if they stayed in the tiny
little town they would have aunts and
uncles and cousins and whole people to
support the marriage but I was
interested in some of the genetic
reasons we do know there's a gene in the
vasopressin system that is likely to
contribute to adultery in a wonderful
study of five hundred and fifty two men
in Sweden those individuals who had one
or two copies of the gene had less
stable relationships which can lead to
cheating they weren't studying adultery
but unstable marriages are going to lead
to adultery we've evolved these three
distinctly different brain systems
attachment feelings of romantic love and
feelings of sex drive and you can feel
deep attachment to one person while you
fall in love with somebody else so the
brain unfortunately is very well built
not only for pair bonding but also for
cheating but of all the data on cheating
and there's a huge amount of it the most
interesting fact that I have found 56
percent of men and 34 percent of women
said that they were in a very happy
marriage but also cheated and it began
to think to myself why would somebody in
a very happy marriage cheat and I began
to think from an evolutionary
perspective what would the payoffs have
been a million years ago of somebody who
cheated dialing back in million years if
a man and a woman formed a pair bond and
had two children fine but if you
occasionally went over the hill hunting
and slept with another woman from
another community and had two extra
children by her he would have created
four children instead of two children he
would have put more of his own DNA into
tomorrow and some of that DNA is going
to carry these predisposition for
adultery
